title: How To Fillet Trout (Rainbow Trout, Brook Trout, & More!)

steps.title: Descale your trout
steps.content: Descale your trout with the back of your knife. Lay your trout on a cutting board and hold it down by its tail. Scrape the backside of your knife from the tail towards the fish’s head. Continue doing this until you don’t lift up any more scales. Clean off your knife and flip the fish over to descale the other side. [1] X Research source You can also purchase a scaler from a kitchen goods store to descale fish.

steps.title: Separate the fish’s gills from its jaw.
steps.content: Separate the fish’s gills from its jaw. Hold the trout over your sink with your non-dominant hand. Put your thumb in the gills of the fish on one side. With your other hand, put the tip of your fillet knife through the small area of skin holding the jaws to the rest of the body. [2] X Research source Keep your thumb away from the knife blade so you don’t accidentally cut yourself.

steps.title: Cut up the stomach from the anus to the gills.
steps.content: Cut up the stomach from the anus to the gills. Find the hole on the bottom of the fish near the tail. Stick your knife in through it and cut up the middle of the stomach toward the gills. When you reach the gills, use the tip of your thumb to break through the last bit of skin. [3] X Research source You can do this while holding the fish over your sink or make it easier by laying the fish down on your cutting board. Choose whichever way feels more comfortable to you.

steps.title: Pull out the gills to remove the innards.
steps.content: Pull out the gills to remove the innards. Pinch the area where the gills meet in the middle between your fingers. Pull the gills down towards the tail to remove all of the trout’s entrails. Throw the entrails away once they’re removed. [4] X Research source Seal the entrails in a plastic bag before throwing them away so your garbage can doesn’t have a fishy odor.

steps.title: Rinse out any blood and residue from inside your fish.
steps.content: Rinse out any blood and residue from inside your fish. Run the fish under a faucet to clean it . Make sure the water is tap cold so it doesn’t cook or change the texture of your fish. Use your fingers inside the stomach cavity to wipe any sand or grit that’s leftover. [5] X Research source Wear thin gloves if you don’t want to touch the inside of the fish directly.

steps.title: Scrape out the mud vein using your thumb.
steps.content: Scrape out the mud vein using your thumb. The mud vein is found near the spine and will look brown in color. Stick your thumb into the trout’s chest cavity and use your nail to scrape it out. Work from the tail end towards the gills. Rinse your fish again to clean any residue from the vein. [6] X Research source If you don’t want to use your thumb, scrape the mud vein out with the edge of a spoon.

steps.title: Pull the head back towards the spine to break the neck.
steps.content: Pull the head back towards the spine to break the neck. Hold the trout’s head in one hand and bend it backward. The neck will pop apart from the rest of the spine so you can remove it easily. [7] X Research source Keep the head attached to the body. This will make it easier to remove the fins later on.

steps.title: Slit underneath the ribs with a fillet knife to separate the bones from the meat.
steps.content: Slit underneath the ribs with a fillet knife to separate the bones from the meat. Start your blade on the inside of the fish near the head. Place the tip between the meat and ribs and slowly work your blade towards the tail. Keep the knife as close to the bones as possible so you don’t waste any of your fillet. Once you have one side finished, flip the fish over and cut the other side away from the ribs. [8] X Research source Trout are smaller fish, so use a blade that’s 4 inches (10 cm) or less so you have more control of where you’re cutting.

steps.title: Poke the knife through the trout’s neck and cut along the spine.
steps.content: Poke the knife through the trout’s neck and cut along the spine. Pull the fillet away from the ribs and put your knife through the skin between the meat and the bones. Keep the blade as close to the spine as you can as you work the knife down through the tail. Flip your fish over and make the same cut on the opposite side. Once both sides are cut, pull the ribs out of the fish and throw them away. [9] X Research source Some small pin bones may stick in your fillet once it’s cut. Work the blade of your knife underneath the bones to cut them away.

steps.title: Remove the front fins and head.
steps.content: Remove the front fins and head. Set the trout upside down so the meat of the fillets is facing up. Put your knife through the skin near the front of one fillet to cut the fin off. Pull the knife across the fish’s neck and the skin around the other fin to remove everything in one piece. [10] X Research source Throw the head away or use it to make fish stock.

steps.title: Cut out the dorsal fin between the fillets.
steps.content: Cut out the dorsal fin between the fillets. Run your knife along the top of each fillet where it connects to the dorsal fin. Once you cut each side, pull the fin out and throw it away. Leave the skin on the fillet for when you cook your trout, regardless of whether you try smoking, grilling or pan-frying it. [11] X Research source
